definition[0]: to give something to someone and get something in return
example[0]: Do you want to swap umbrellas?
example[1]: He swapped his watch for a box of cigars.
example[2]: The girls chatted and swapped clothes with each other.
definition[1]: to tell information to someone and be given information in return
example[3]: We need to get together to swap ideas and information.
example[4]: They sat in a corner and swapped gossip.
definition[2]: to do the thing that someone else has been doing, and let them do the thing that you have been doing
example[5]: They decided to swap roles for the day.
example[6]: You start on the windows and I’ll do the walls, then we can swap over after an hour or so.
example[7]: She ended up swapping jobs with her secretary.
definition[3]: to stop using or get rid of one thing and put or get another thing in its place
example[8]: The driver announced that we would have to swap buses.
example[9]: She had swapped her long skirts for jeans and T-shirts.
example[10]: He swapped his London home for a cottage in Scotland.
definition[4]: to move one thing and put another in its place
example[11]: Someone had gone into the nursery and swapped all the babies around.
example[12]: Why don’t we swap the TV with the bookcase?
definition[5]: a situation in which you give something to someone and get another thing in return
example[14]: We can do a swap if you like.
definition[6]: a situation in which people each do the job that the other usually does
definition[7]: to exchange one investment for another
example[15]: Investors have doubled their money afterswapping thebonds for a package of cash and shares.
example[16]: Employees were allowed to swap old, effectively worthlessstock for new options.
definition[8]: an exchange of one investment for another
example[17]: The tax-free stock swap was valued at almost $880 million.
example[18]: The Accounting Standards Board has launched a project to valuedebt-for-equity swaps more accurately.
